This sounds like a very useful utility.

The first thing I would consider is implementing the code in the
following stages: 
1) Given header info and a template, calculate a file name.
2) Read an mp3 header from a file
3) Rename a given file
4) Search for all files of interest in a directory
5) Put the pieces together so that you can launch your utility on a file
or directory and have it do its thing


So you write your tests first and implement the code to make the tests
work in the following order:
1) Write a set of tests for #1. Build your own mp3 headers to test with
2) Write a set of tests for #2. Compare headers read in with those you
build. It would be extra nice if you can reuse the headers you built for
#1. 
3) Write a test for #3 that just takes a test file, and renames it and
then changes it back.
4) Write a test for #4 that looks for files in a test directory. Add
variations for boundary conditions. 
5) Acceptance test: given a test directory full of files (of various
interesting variations), run the utility and validate that the files
have been renamed correctly

Note 1: it is assumed that you will be including assertions in your
tests above that validate that you are getting what you expect.
Note 2: Your focus in tests #2, #3, and #4 is validating that you are
calling the library code correctly, rather than the testing the library
code itself.
Note 3: It could be argued that for a small application like this you
could write test #5 first without all the other tests and if it works
then you are done. That runs counter to test-first and misses all the
design and documentation benefits you get from that. Plus if it doesn't
work you'll wish you had tests #1-4 to help you isolate the problem.

> I'm a relative neophyte to unit testing.  I don't have much 
> trouble in writing tests for new code for existing apps, but 
> can't seem to get my head around test-first from the ground 
> up on a new app.
> 
> As an example, I recently wrote a small utility that views 
> the header info of an mp3, and renames the file from the 
> information contained therein.  You pass it (on the command 
> line) the name of a directory or file, and a 'template' which 
> includes the format of the name it should generate.  If a 
> file is passed, it renames the file.  If a directory is 
> passed, it recursively renames all files in the directory.  
> An example name template would be something like "%b - %n" 
> for "Artist - Track Title".
> 
> I actually got halfway finished with it, then deleted all of 
> my code, since I hadn't done it test-first, but then couldn't 
> think how to go about testing it.  I'm using an external lib 
> (jd3lib) for reading mp3 header info, and the standard 
> java.io stuff for file manipulation. Every test I can think 
> of would just test external code (reading mpeg header info, 
> file renaming, etc), so I'm somewhat at a loss.  Is there 
> anyone out there who'd like to get me started with a couple tests?
> 
> Thanx much,
> BRiaN
